entry.title: Making the labour market more flexible, efficient and fair
entry.summary: How the government is changing employment laws to encourage companies to hire staff while protecting employee rights.
entry.content:
Issue

Businesses say current employment laws are difficult to cope with and put them off taking on staff. This slows the growth of businesses and the economy.

Simpler, more flexible employment laws will make it easier for companies to hire and manage staff, while protecting basic workers’ rights. This should encourage employers to create new jobs, supporting enterprise and growth.

Actions

To make the labour market more flexible, efficient and fair the government is:

  • reviewing employment laws
  • introducing more flexible working practices for parents and older workers
  • setting and enforcing National Minimum Wage rates to protect workers from exploitation and businesses from unfair competition
  • making it easier for businesses to employ people and for employees to balance work and family commitments
  • providing better guidance on employment law
  • enforcing standards in employment agencies and employment businesses and recruitment agencies to better protect workers
  • researching the labour market to produce data on employment relations, the labour market and equality at work

Background

We agreed to review employment law in May 2010 as part of the Coalition Agreement.

The Red Tape Challenge to reduce regulations launched in April 2011 and includes a review of employment law.

We’ve already:

  • extended the time you need to be employed to be able to claim for unfair dismissal from 1 to 2 years
  • introduced the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Bill which will make changes to the employment tribunal system, including ensuring all employment tribunal claims go to Acas and introducing a simpler process
  • removed the compulsory retirement age, making it easier for older people to carry on working
  • launched a pilot scheme encouraging the use of mediation to resolve disputes
  • reviewed how employment rights are enforced

Who we are consulting

We’ve carried out consultations on:

  • resolving workplace disputes more quickly without having to go to an employment tribunal
  • changing the rules on large-scale redundancies so that employers can restructure more effectively while also carrying out good quality consultations
  • changing the rules on ending the employment relationship, the use of settlement agreements and changes to the compensation limit in unfair dismissal cases
  • changing employment tribunal rules to make them more flexible and effective and to get better value for the taxpayer

Impact

We’ve carried out an impact assessment on the benefits of resolving workplace disputes. We estimate these changes will save businesses £40 million a year.

entry.title: Growth and Infrastructure Bill Clause 23 [employer owners]: impact assessment
entry.summary: Assesses the impact of proposed legislation to give companies greater choice about the contracts they can offer to individuals.
entry.content: Assesses the impact for businesses and individuals of proposed legislation to give companies greater choice about the contracts they can offer to individuals, whilst ensuring appropriate levels of protection are maintained. The government is creating a new employment status of ‘employee owner’, where employee owners receive shares but will not have certain employment rights relating to unfair dismissal flexible working and training, and statutory redundancy pay. See also the consultation on this employee ownership

entry.title: Implementing employee owner status: government response to consultation
entry.content: Summarises responses received and provides the government response to the consultation on how the government will implement employer owner status. This aims to give businesses greater choice about the contracts they can offer employees, whilst ensuring appropriate levels of protection are maintained.

entry.title: TUPE - a guide to the 2006 regulations
entry.summary: Guidance on the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 - for employers, employees and representatives.
entry.content:
The revised Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations came into force in 2006. These regulations provide rights to employees when their employer changes when a business is transferred to a new owner.

This publication provides guidance to employers, employees and their representatives to help them understand the regulations and comply with their legal requirements.

Please note, this is general guidance; it should not be taken as a complete or authoritative statement of the law.

entry.title: Regional Growth Fund confirmatory due diligence
entry.content: Advice for regional growth fund (RGF) round 3 that explains who is eligible to be a due diligence provider to prepare a confirmatory due diligence report for RGF bids. This is required to confirm that their project or programme represents value for money and that it will deliver the benefits set out in their application. The scope of the due diligence report must be agreed by BIS and the bidder, and the Department must approve an applicant’s choice of due diligence provider. This guide also explains how due diligence providers can be engaged as an approved organisation and outlines the scope of the due diligence required.

entry.title: The Parental Leave (EU Directive) Regulations 2013: impact assessment
entry.content: Assesses the impact from draft regulations (URN 12/1284) that extend UK parental leave legislation to comply with EU Directive 2010/18 on Parental Leave by 2013. It intends to implement the Parental Leave Directive to encourage shared parenting and maintain attachment to the labour market whilst minimising burdens to business. This supports the proposed new system of flexible parental leave due to be introduced in 2015.

entry.title: Modern workplaces consultation: government response on flexible working. Impact assessment
entry.content: Assesses the impact of proposals to extend the right to request flexible working to all employees. These proposals aim to facilitate the employee-employer information exchange that can increase the availability and take-up of flexible working, provide all employees with the same access to flexible working, and improve the functioning of the labour market. Relates to the closed consultation on modern workplaces (URN 11/699). See also 12/1269 for the government response and 12/1271 for the equality impact assessment.Underlying data for this publication is available in a machine processable format on the Transparency/Report Data webpage.

entry.title: Modern workplaces [consultation]: government response on flexible parental leave. Impact assessment
entry.content: Assesses the impact of proposals on extending flexible parental leave in the closed consultation on modern workplaces (URN 11/699). The new system of flexible parental leave aims to give parents more choice and flexibility in how they care for their child in the first year, encourage more fathers to play a greater caring role, and increase flexibility for employers and employees to reach agreement. See also 12/1267 for the government response and 12/1271 for the equality impact assessment. Underlying data for this publication is available in a machine processable format on the Transparency/Report Data webpage.

entry.title: Modern workplaces [consultation]: government response on flexible parental leave
entry.content: Government response to flexible parental leave elements of the closed consultation on modern workplaces (URN 11/699). Summarises public responses to the consultation and explains how the government will implement measures to encourage fathers to take a greater role in caring for their babies. These measures will also enable working families to be able to share the leave and pay that is currently only available for the mother. See 12/1268 for the related impact assessment and 12/1271 for the equality impact assessment.
